channel.title: Health Care
channel.description: News, Analysis and Opinion from POLITICO

item.title: Trump jettisons the GOP’s corporate allies in health care plan
item.description: The president pointed the finger at insurers and pharma in calling for price cuts to help stressed voters.

media:content.media:title: Trump's plan aims to unite a party that's long struggled to settle on a health care message.

item.dc:creator: By Amanda Chu, David Lim, Robert King and Kelly Hooper
item.dc:contributor: By Amanda Chu, David Lim, Robert King and Kelly Hooper

item.title: Democrats make pitch to keep no-premium Obamacare plans
item.description: While Republicans believe the plans encourage fraud, Democrats worry that raising premiums will prompt lower-income enrollees to drop coverage.

media:content.media:title: Sen. Raphael Warnock, D-Ga., has been pushing his GOP colleagues to keep zero-dollar premium plans in bipartisan talks to extend enhanced Obamacare subsidies.

item.dc:creator: By Robert King
item.dc:contributor: By Robert King

item.title: Abortion opponents threaten to withhold midterm support amid rift with Trump
item.description: Amid concerns about the president's actions, abortion opponents are threatening to redirect or withhold campaign spending and withdraw their volunteer armies in the midterms.

media:content.media:title: Pro-life demonstrators listen to former President Donald Trump as he speaks at the 47th annual "March for Life" in Washington, DC, on January 24, 2020.

item.dc:creator: By Alice Miranda Ollstein and Megan Messerly
item.dc:contributor: By Alice Miranda Ollstein and Megan Messerly

item.title: HHS terminates, then reinstates, thousands of grants for substance use, mental health
item.description: The Department of Health and Human Services told grantees their projects were no longer aligned with agency priorities, then backtracked under pressure.

media:content.media:title: The Trump administration began slashing thousands of grants dedicated to mental health treatment and substance abuse recovery Tuesday.

item.dc:creator: By Carmen Paun and Amanda Friedman
item.dc:contributor: By Carmen Paun and Amanda Friedman

item.title: National health spending soared for 2nd consecutive year in 2024
item.description: The 7.2 percent increase comes as Americans continue to seek out medical care at high levels.

media:content.media:title: Americans have continued to seek out high levels of medical care — including hospital, doctor and prescription drug services — in the aftermath of the Covid pandemic.

item.dc:creator: By Kelly Hooper
item.dc:contributor: By Kelly Hooper

item.title: Lawsuit dismissed after Trump admin quietly restored tens of millions to Planned Parenthood
item.description: Progressive groups dropped their case against HHS over the withheld family planning funds, but other challenges continue.

media:content.media:title: Though lawsuits continue about a far bigger cut to Planned Parenthood's federal Medicaid funds, the restoration of Title X funding will help many clinics keep their doors open. (Photo by Kayla Bartkowski/Getty Images)

item.dc:creator: By Alice Miranda Ollstein
item.dc:contributor: By Alice Miranda Ollstein

item.title: RFK Jr.’s theories about vaccines are about to be tested
item.description: American kids are no longer routinely being recommended shots against hepatitis A, meningitis, rotavirus and the flu.

media:content.media:title: HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s move to downgrade several childhood vaccine recommendations will likely have consequences, public health experts say.

item.dc:creator: By Sophie Gardner
item.dc:contributor: By Sophie Gardner

item.title: Parents on RFK Jr.’s advice on sweets: ‘Completely unrealistic’
item.description: The health secretary’s new dietary guidelines tell parents to cut the added sugar until their kids turn 11.

media:content.media:title: The new guidelines are the government’s declaration of war on added sugar, Kennedy said this week. Brandon Bell

item.dc:creator: By Carmen Paun and Grace Yarrow
item.dc:contributor: By Carmen Paun and Grace Yarrow

item.title: Trump’s plan to strong-arm insurers into lower prices is met with skepticism
item.description: There are reasons to be skeptical that voluntary cuts by insurance companies could bring significant, lasting health care savings for Americans.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump announces a deal to lower drug prices in the Oval Office.

item.dc:creator: By Cheyenne Haslett
item.dc:contributor: By Cheyenne Haslett

item.title: The GOP's Obamacare defectors were more numerous than expected
item.description: The group was led by members in swing seats and those who represent many constituents facing rising health insurance premiums.

media:content.media:title: Wisconsin Rep. Derrick Van Orden was a surprise yes vote on Democrats' bill to restore expired Obamacare subsidies.

item.dc:creator: By Lisa Kashinsky and Simon J. Levien
item.dc:contributor: By Lisa Kashinsky and Simon J. Levien

item.title: The big plan behind Kennedy’s overhaul of childhood vaccines
item.description: Here’s how the downgrading of shots could make it easier for people who claim vaccine injuries to sue for millions, driving manufacturers from the market.

media:content.media:title: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. attends an event on Oct. 16, 2025, where President Donald Trump delivered remarks in the Oval Office of the White House. Kennedy's department announced an overhaul of the childhood vaccine schedule on Jan. 5, 2026, a month after Trump directed him to compare American recommendations to those made in "peer, developed" nations.

item.dc:creator: By Lauren Gardner
item.dc:contributor: By Lauren Gardner

item.title: Senators confirm Trump’s drug czar
Conservatives balk at Trump’s calls to be ‘flexible’ on abortion coverage in health care talks
item.description: The president’s remarks come at a tenuous time, as many lawmakers are holding out hope for a compromise bill to extend lapsed Obamacare subsidies.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump points to the crowd as he walks off stage after speaking to House Republican lawmakers during their annual policy retreat, Jan. 6, 2026, in Washington.

item.dc:creator: By Meredith Lee Hill and Benjamin Guggenheim
item.dc:contributor: By Meredith Lee Hill and Benjamin Guggenheim

item.title: Artificial intelligence begins prescribing medications in Utah
item.description: Pilot program will test how far patients and regulators are willing to trust AI in medicine.

media:content.media:title: Doctronic AI

item.dc:creator: By Yasmin Khorram and Ruth Reader
item.dc:contributor: By Yasmin Khorram and Ruth Reader

item.title: HHS dramatically overhauls childhood vaccine schedule, downgrading advice for flu, meningitis, other shots
item.description: Federal officials say the U.S. schedule should be more in line with recommendations in other countries. Public health experts say the goal belies differences between health systems and disease prevalence.

media:content.media:title: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. speaks during an event with President Donald Trump in the Roosevelt Room of the White House on Dec. 19, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Lauren Gardner
item.dc:contributor: By Lauren Gardner

item.title: Trump’s embrace of pot has Republicans in Congress fuming
item.description: In moving to reduce marijuana regulation, the president has defied the party’s old guard.

media:content.media:title: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. endorsed President Donald Trump's plan to reclassify marijuana as a less dangerous drug in December.

item.dc:creator: By Lauren Brensel and Amanda Friedman
item.dc:contributor: By Lauren Brensel and Amanda Friedman

item.title: Trump’s drug-pricing deals won’t benefit most Americans today. They could over time.
item.description: Most Americans likely will not benefit immediately from efforts to lower prescription prices. Administration officials expect effects to spread as markets are reshaped.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump indicated more drug pricing deals will be unveiled soon.

item.dc:creator: By David Lim
item.dc:contributor: By David Lim

item.title: States step into the breach as Obamacare subsidies lapse
item.description: Even state governments that want to help can’t completely cover rising insurance premiums.

media:content.media:title: An Obamacare sign is displayed outside an insurance agency on Nov. 12 in Miami, Florida.

item.dc:creator: By Alice Miranda Ollstein and Natalie Fertig
item.dc:contributor: By Alice Miranda Ollstein and Natalie Fertig

item.title: Trump admin doles out billions for rural health
item.description: Montana and California will receive near equal amounts in 2026, despite their massive size disparity.

media:content.media:title: CMS Administrator Mehmet Oz speaks during an event in the Roosevelt Room of the White House, Dec. 19, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Alice Miranda Ollstein and Ruth Reader
item.dc:contributor: By Alice Miranda Ollstein and Ruth Reader

item.title: The miracle cure for sickle cell is now 2 years old. Most are still waiting.
item.description: Despite a Trump administration push, there are few facilities offering the complex treatment in the rural areas where many patients live.

media:content.media:title: Cell lines are prepared in the laboratory of Dr. John Tisdale — a senior investigator at the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute's Cellular and Molecular Therapeutics Laboratory at the National Institutes of Health — who led early gene therapy trials to treat sickle cell disease.

item.dc:creator: By Kelly Hooper
item.dc:contributor: By Kelly Hooper

item.title: The ultraprocessed food makers have an answer for RFK Jr.
item.description: The companies behind Doritos, Oscar Mayer wieners, and Kraft Mac & Cheese are warning state regulation promoted by the health secretary is driving up your food bill.

media:content.media:title: Lobbying spending by major food companies and their trade associations has reached record highs this year.

item.dc:creator: By Amanda Chu
item.dc:contributor: By Amanda Chu

item.title: Why RFK Jr.’s plan to follow Europe on vaccines is getting panned
item.description: In some cases, Europe has better contained disease, in others it’s let them spread to keep costs down.

media:content.media:title: Denmark advises immunizing against only 10 of the 18 diseases American children were historically recommended immunizations against.

item.dc:creator: By Lauren Gardner, Carmen Paun and Sophie Gardner
item.dc:contributor: By Lauren Gardner, Carmen Paun and Sophie Gardner

item.title: States see possible warning signs amid steady Obamacare sign-ups
item.description: While sign-ups are above 2024, some states are concerned about higher terminations, fewer new enrollees and more consumer calls for help. If Congress fails again to extend enhanced subsidies in January, they say enrollment could drop.

media:content.media:title: Several state Obamacare exchanges say new enrollment is off compared to prior years, even though the latest federal figures show enrollment overall is steady.

item.dc:creator: By Robert King
item.dc:contributor: By Robert King

item.title: RFK Jr. wanted to endorse the Danish vaccine schedule. He was forced to pull back.
item.description: Legal and political concerns prompted the health department to cancel a planned announcement on Friday, officials said.

media:content.media:title: Trump earlier this month directed Kennedy to examine the Danish schedule.

item.dc:creator: By Tim Röhn
item.dc:contributor: By Tim Röhn

item.title: Trump announces drug pricing deals with nine drugmakers, touting impact on affordability
item.description: The President said more deals would be announced next week, and suggested White House pressure will also come to bear on health insurers soon.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump hosted drugmaker executives at the White House on Friday.

item.dc:creator: By David Lim and Cheyenne Haslett
item.dc:contributor: By David Lim and Cheyenne Haslett

item.title: Republicans are trying to change the subject on health care affordability — to transgender care
item.description: In a spate of votes and announcements, the GOP is tacking hard to an issue where the party sees an advantage.

media:content.media:title: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said he thought doctors who provide gender-affirming care were violating their oath to do no harm.

item.dc:creator: By Simon J. Levien and Jessica Piper
item.dc:contributor: By Simon J. Levien and Jessica Piper

item.title: Trump signs executive order to ease marijuana restrictions
item.description: The move could fuel more research and provide tax breaks to cannabis companies.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump's executive order could fuel more marijuana research and provide tax breaks to cannabis companies.

item.dc:creator: By Lauren Brensel and Amanda Friedman
item.dc:contributor: By Lauren Brensel and Amanda Friedman

item.title: It’s now time for the Obamacare blame game
item.description: With insurance rates spiking and Congress stalemated, professional advocates are swooping in to shape the narrative.

media:content.media:title: House Speaker Mike Johnson and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries confer as they arrive for a vigil for Sarah Milgrim and Yaron Lischinsky outside the U.S. Capitol June 10, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Amanda Chu
item.dc:contributor: By Amanda Chu

item.title: Despite a possible agreement on ACA subsidies, abortion lurks as a hurdle
item.description: Abortion-rights and anti-abortion groups warn lawmakers that if they buck them, they will pay in the midterms

media:content.media:title: FILE - Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., left, and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, D-N.Y., meet with reporters to speak about health care affordability at the Capitol in Washington, Dec. 3, 2025. (AP Photo/J. Scott Applewhite, file)

item.dc:creator: By Alice Miranda Ollstein and Robert King
item.dc:contributor: By Alice Miranda Ollstein and Robert King

item.title: House GOP health package lowers spending but boosts uninsured
